The cruise control switches are used as PTO controls (if vehicle is so equipped) when the vehicle road speed is not present (this is an owner selected parameter). Refer to the Owners Manual furnished with the vehicle for Cruise Control operating instructions.

svcsubproc.title: Cruise ON/OFF Switch (419)
svcsubproc.para:
Refer to
CIRCUIT DIAGRAMS, Figure 6.05 or Figure 6.08
, for this discussion.
This is a lighted switch (refer to Lighted Switches for light feature).

Cruise ON/OFF switch circuit (97AE) is an input to the ECM through connector (558) terminal 20. The ground side of the ON/OFF switch is connected through circuit 97-GH/97-GA/97-G to connector (558) terminal 29. With the switch ON, the ECM sees 0 volts at connector (558) terminal 20. With the switch OFF, the ECM sees 5 volts at connector (558) terminal 20.

svcsubproc.title: Cruise Set/Resume Switch (418)
svcsubproc.para:
Refer to
CIRCUIT DIAGRAMS, Figure 6.05 or Figure 6.08
, for this discussion.
This is a lighted switch (refer to Lighted Switches for light feature).

SET/RESUME switch terminal 2 is connected through common circuit (97-GD/97-GA/97-G) to connector (558) terminal 29. SET/RESUME switch SET terminal 3 is an input (circuit 97AB) to the ECM through connector (558) terminal 25. SET/RESUME switch RESUME terminal (1) is an input (circuit 97AA) to the ECM through connector (558) terminal 15.
With the SET/RESUME switch in the SET position, the ECM sees 0 volts at connector (558) terminal 25 and 5 volts at terminal 15.
In RESUME position, the ECM sees 5 volts at connector (558) terminal 25 and 0 volts at terminal 15.
In the SET/RESUME neutral position, the ECM sees 5 volts at both connector (558) terminals 15 and 25.

svcsubproc.title: Service Brake Switch (317)
svcsubproc.para:
Refer to
CIRCUIT DIAGRAMS, Figure 6.05
or Figure 6.08
, for this discussion.

Service brake switch circuit 97AL is an input to the ECM through connector (558) terminal 14. The ground or common side of the Service Brake switch is connected through circuit 97-GB/97-GA/97-G to connector (558) terminal 29. With service brakes released (switch closed), the ECM sees 0 volts at connector (558) terminal 14. Applying the brakes opens the switch, and the ECM sees 5 volts at terminal 14.

svcsubproc.title: Clutch Switch
svcsubproc.para:
Refer to
CIRCUIT DIAGRAMS, Figure 6.05 or Figure 6.08
, for this discussion.
The Clutch Switch is a normally open switch, that is adjusted to be closed while the clutch pedal is RELEASED.

The clutch switch connects to the cab harness at connector (55). Clutch switch circuit (97AH) is an input to the ECM through connector (558) terminal 24. The ground side of the clutch pedal switch is grounded through circuit 97-GE/97-GA/97-G to connector (558) terminal 29. With the driver's foot off the clutch pedal (switch closed), the ECM sees 0 volts at terminal 24. When the driver depresses the clutch pedal (switch opens), the ECM sees 5 volts at terminal 24.

svcsubproc.title: Vehicle Speed Sensor (225)
svcsubproc.para:
Refer to
CIRCUIT DIAGRAMS, Figure 6.05 or Figure 6.08
for this discussion.

The Vehicle Speed Sensor is located at the rear of the transmission. The sensor contains a permanent magnet that creates a magnetic field that is interrupted by the teeth on the speedometer output gear. As the rotating speedometer gear teeth repeatedly interrupt the sensor magnetic field, a variable AC voltage is generated and transmitted to the ECM. From sensor connector (225) circuits 97AJ and 97AK carry the signal to ECM connector (558) terminals 12 and 18.

svcsubproc.title: Lighted Switches
svcsubproc.para:
The cab switches contain two Light Emitting Diodes (LED) that illuminate the switch when the panel lights are ON. The symbol used for this type switch is shown in Figure 2.04. The LED receives at voltage at terminal 7, from the panel light dimmer switch through Panel Light Feed Adapter (504), so the brightness of the light is adjusted with the panel lights. There is a current limiting resistor in the switch to protect the diodes. Note however, that an LED is normally either ON or OFF, but will dim somewhat when the panel lights are turned down, but if turned down very much the LED goes out.
The LEDs are grounded at terminal 8, through the Panel Light Ground Adapter (505).
